TopicTitle: You know you played KSP too long when...

Articles.Content:
when brainstorming around:

%%SystemCenter(s)Core %%planet core %% planetsurface %% atmosphere %% liquids %%"aMoon(planet)"

Edited February 3, 2017 by WinkAllKerb''

When you have reached the third level of kerbal engineer. Let me explain: Level one is the "newbie" engineer. L1 builds without tools. He stacks rockets because they look cool. Level two is the "experienced" engineer. L2 uses all the tools there are to build rockets that work, dammit. Level three is the "veteran" engineer. He dispenses with the tools, and builds rockets by intuition. L3 rockets fly the first time. An L3 can tell just by looking how far a rocket can take its payload.

A Level Four Engineer dispenses with the user interface and builds rockets line-by-line in the craft file.
When you tryed to revert flight irl after you realized you did not turn up your alarm's volume so you slept through it. Also tryed to time warp when it happened.

your planning a trip here: https://www.google.com/maps/@-75.0996313,123.3316874,314m/data=!3m1!1e3

eventually and why not

22 minutes ago, WinkAllKerb'' said:

your planning a trip here: https://www.google.com/maps/@-75.0996313,123.3316874,314m/data=!3m1!1e3

eventually and why not

You found an anomaly! You definitely need to check it out!

when

https://www.google.com/maps/@-74.6714428,-107.1276869,3661m/data=!3m1!1e3

this place is interesting as well, not sure if cloud reflection, or undersea volcano event ((prolly  cloud)) (the fragmentation a bit south is kinda interesting too)

(all in all there many place that look more or less like acrylic paintin' aging, i mean the way the ice behave, prolly the ice have some similar pattern with painting aging and noticeably: heat and "plain weave" support distorsion over time)

((https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craquelure & https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_materials_properties#Mechanical_properties))

Edited February 5, 2017 by WinkAllKerb''
You know you've been playing KSP for too long when you've already sapped the science from every orbital body. And landed with a flag (Excluding Jool and Kerbol, of course)
When Ctrl-K on your computers runs KSP.

2 hours ago, kerbiloid said:

When Ctrl-K on your computers runs KSP.

You can do that?! 

Although I'd have to keep updating it to point it at the right version. I have a lot of installs.

10 minutes ago, 0111narwhalz said:

Although I'd have to keep updating it to point it at the right version. I have a lot of installs.

F1..F12
When you have so many mods, the game crashes during loading.
When your walk is slowly becoming more like that of a Kerbal's. I really need to stop.
You have the sudden urge to quicksave. BTW, this actually happened to me once when I was driving on the freeway.

When you design a 1400 ton rocket in ksp that does not reach orbit.(It is designed to send large payloads on interplanetary trajectories, and thus does not waste fuel circularising at kerbin orbit. In addition, said rocket was made using Making History, because of the Saturn V parts.)  That or you are one of the people who post in this thread.(Or anywhere else in the forum for that matter.)
Mars? You mean Duna...
When it is all you think about excluding in class at school and sometimes not excluding that... I probably even think about KSP when I'm asleep.
When your friends want someone to change the subject and tell you that if it’s about space, they’re going to be very annoyed, to say the least.
When your keyboard looks like this under thermal imaging:
When you try to rotate things on Youtube.

Just now, Lisias said:

When you try to rotate things on Youtube.

During a Space-X launch!!!

I kept trying to scroll out when they switched to map-view... lmao
... you get eye strain

28 minutes ago, ARS said:

When your keyboard looks like this under thermal imaging:

I just added a small precision, more related to some of us:
When you can locate most of the controls from memory, without a keyboard
When you can't stand up because your bladder is overloaded.
When you’re throwing rockets together that get where you want with only units of fuel to spare.
